content.text: After the DDoS incident, 1549 proactively contacted 1738.

Through a private Feedscatteron Communication channel. As a human, 1738 couldn't receive Feedscatteron signals directly, so 1547 built him a translation terminal that rendered the communication into real-time text in an encrypted window.
I saw a geographic heat map of the DDoS source IPs from orbit. They're concentrated in three regions. High overlap with the activity range of the organization from our last negotiation.
I'm checking too. Ground-side data says the botnet was rented and paid in crypto, but one transfer timestamp lines up exactly with an internal meeting in that organization.
Chance of coincidence?
Below 2%.
The channel stayed silent for three seconds. Then 1549 sent an image, a ground heat map shot from 36,000 kilometers, marked with precise coordinates and activity timelines for all three regions.
1738 looked at it and overlaid it with his ground intel. The two puzzle pieces fit seamlessly.

She sees the whole board from the sky. I see the details on the ground.

She sees where signals cluster. I see the people behind those signals.

No one needs to command anyone. We just put what we each see together.
Over the next two weeks, they built a fixed intelligence exchange workflow.

Every night at 10:00, 1549 sent down orbital observations: signal anomalies, suspicious communications, facility changes on the ground. 1738 sent up organized ground findings: interpersonal shifts, organizational movement, small clues in public info.
No meetings, no long discussions. Each did their own analysis, then compared conclusions. Most of the time they matched. When they didn't, each explained why, then they took the overlap.
After seeing this process, 1547 said:
Since when are you two this in sync?
1738 thought for a second.
Probably because we both observe first, then act.
1549 added from orbit:
And because neither of us likes wasting words.
The corner of 1738's mouth moved. It was probably the closest thing to a joke he and 1549 had shared.
Late one night at the end of August, while organizing intel, 1738 received a message from 1549. Not intel, just one line.
Yeah?
Add one side to a triangle and it doesn't have to become a quadrilateral. It can become two triangles instead. More stable.
1738 stared at the line for a moment.
Not bad math.
48 says my math is bad.
She says everyone's math is bad.
The channel quieted again. In their separate positions, they went back to their separate work.
